thread.title: Texas-size battle in ALDS: Blue Jays’ lineup
thread.title_full: Texas-size battle in ALDS: Blue Jays’ lineup

title: Texas-size battle in ALDS: Blue Jays’ lineup
text:
Texas-size battle in ALDS: Blue Jays’ lineup October 8, 2015 Last updated: Thursday, October 8, 2015, 1:21 AM THE ASSOCIATED PRESS | Print 
TORONTO — For some pitchers trying to stop Josh Donaldson and the rest of the powerful Blue Jays, it's enough to take their breath away. 
"You can't let up," Texas Rangers closer Shawn Tolleson said a day ahead of today's AL Division Series opener. "There's no getting past one guy and taking an exhale." 
Still, in their final series of the regular season, a four-game showdown against the Angels, the Rangers' pitching staff got something of a warm-up for facing the bashing Blue Jays. 
"We've tried to do a good job this season about keeping the mind-set of never letting up," Tolleson said. "We had those same talks when playing Anaheim … pitching to [Mike] Trout and [Albert] Pujols and then you face [C.J.] Cron." 
Good practice, for sure, but Toronto's deep lineup will present even tougher challenges, with AL MVP candidate Donaldson followed by sluggers Jose Bautista and Edwin Encarnacion. Shortstop Troy Tulowitzki and catcher Russell Martin aren't far behind. 
"Our lineup is legit," Donaldson said. "One through nine, I feel like we have probably the best lineup in baseball." 
Astros, K.C. similar 
KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When the Houston Astros had recorded the final out in Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night, they flooded onto the field in a wild celebration — making all their years of losing finally a memory. 
It looked a whole lot like the scene in Kansas City a year ago. 
Now, the long-suffering Astros will try to accomplish what the once-beleaguered Royals did by building on their wild-card victory over the Yankees. They visit Kansas City to begin a best-of-five AL Division Series against the Royals tonight at Kauffman Stadium. 
"It kind of reminds us of us last year," Royals third baseman Mike Moustakas said after a light workout Wednesday afternoon, "young and hungry and out there trying to prove to everybody that we deserve to be here." 
The Royals certainly accomplished that 12 months ago. 
After ending a 29-year postseason drought, the plucky bunch of youngsters went all the way to the World Series, where they fell in seven games to the San Francisco Giants. 
But it was the Royals' dramatic, extra-inning victory over the Oakland Athletics in their AL wild-card game that instilled in them a belief that they could play with anybody in baseball.
